Kumm.]] }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Hygrophorus eburneus'' | whichGills = decurrent | capShape = convex | capShape2 = flat | hymeniumType = gills | stipeCharacter = bare | ecologicalType = mycorrhizal | sporePrintColor = white | howEdible = edible }} {{stack end}} '''''Hygrophorus eburneus''''', commonly known as the '''ivory waxy cap''' or the '''cowboy's handkerchief''', is a species of [[edible mushroom]] in the [[Hygrophoraceae|waxgill family]] of [[fungi]]. It is widespread in Europe and North America, and has also been collected in northern Africa. The [[basidiocarp|fruit bodies]] are medium-sized, pure white, and when wet are covered in a layer of slime thick enough to make the mushroom difficult to pick up. The [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] are broadly attached to the [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] or running down it; as the family name suggests, they feel waxy when rubbed between the fingers. Like all ''Hygrophorus'' species, the fungus is [[mycorrhiza]]l—a [[symbiosis|symbiotic]] association whereby the underground fungal [[Mycelium|mycelia]] penetrate and exchange nutrients with tree roots. They are common in a variety of forest types, where they grow on the ground in thickets or grassy areas. ''Hygrophorus eburneus'' is the [[type species]] of the genus ''Hygrophorus''. A number of [[biological activity|biologically active]] chemicals have been purified from the fruit bodies of the fungus, including [[fatty acid]]s with [[bactericide|bactericidal]] and [[fungicide|fungicidal]] activity. ==Taxonomy== The species was first named as ''Agaricus eburneus'' by French botanist [[Jean Baptiste François Pierre Bulliard|Jean Bulliard]] in 1783. [[Elias Fries]] divided the large genus ''Agaricus'' into a number of "tribes" ([[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomically]] equivalent to modern [[section (botany)|sections]]) in his ''Systema Mycologicum I'', and classified ''A. eburneus'' in the tribe ''Limacium''. When In 1836, Fries first defined the genus ''[[Hygrophorus]]'' in his ''Epicrisis Systematis Mycologici'', ''H. eburneus'' was included. The fungus has also been named ''Limacium eburneum'' by [[Paul Kummer]] in 1871, when he raised the tribes of Fries to the rank of genus, and ''Gymnopus eburneus'' by [[Samuel Frederick Gray]] in 1821. ''H. eburneus'' is the [[type species]] of the genus ''Hygrophorus'', and is classified in the section ''Hygrophorus'', subsection ''Hygrophorus''. This includes species with non-[[amyloid (mycology)|amyloid]], smooth [[basidiospore|spores]], and divergent [[hypha]]e in the tissue of the [[hymenium]]. Other species in this subsection include ''[[Hygrophorus eburneiformis|H. eburneiformis]]'', ''[[Hygrophorus coccus|H. coccus]]'', ''[[Hygrophorus ponderatus|H. ponderatus]]'', ''[[Hygrophorus chrysaspis|H. chrysaspis]]'', and ''[[Hygrophorus glutinosus|H. glutinosus]]''.Hesler and Smith, 1963, p. 248. The mushroom is [[common name|commonly]] known as the "ivory waxy cap", the "white waxy cap", or the "cowboy's handkerchief". The [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] ''eburneus'' is a [[Latin]] adjective meaning "of ivory". ==Description== [[File:Elfenbeinschneckling Hygrophorus eburneus.jpg|thumb|left|The species is characterized by its extremely slimy cap.]] The [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] of ''H. eburneus'' is {{convert|2|to|7|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} broad, with a shape ranging from convex to flattened, sometimes with an [[umbo (mycology)|umbo]] (a raised area in the center of the cap). In age the cap margin sometimes becomes elevated and the center of the cap depressed. The cap is pure white, and depending on the moisture in the environment, may be [[wikt:glutinous|glutinous]] to sticky. The cap surface is smooth, the margin is even and in young specimens, rolled inward and covered with short fibrils. The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is white, thick in the center of the cap but thinning toward the margin. The odor and taste are mild. The [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] are somewhat arcuate-decurrent, meaning they are shaped like a bow, curving upward and then running down the stem for a short distance. In terms of spacing, they are subdistant to distant, so that space can be seen between them. The gills are moderately broad, broadest near the stem, narrowed in front, pure white, slightly yellowish or [[buff (color)|buff]] with age or when dried. The [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] is {{convert|4.5|to|15|cm|in|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|2|to|8|mm|in|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} thick, equal in width throughout its length to somewhat tapered downward or with a greatly attenuated base, and glutinous. Its surface is silky beneath the gluten. The top of the stem is covered with short fibrils, pure white, sometimes becoming grayish or dirty with age. It is initially stuffed with cotton-like [[mycelium|mycelia]], then later becomes hollow. The caps of dried fruit bodies will typically remain white, while the stems will dry darker, especially if they are initially waterlogged.Smith, 1947, pp. 253–55. ===Microscopic characteristics=== [[File:Hygrophorus eburneus 64703.jpg|thumb|right|Spores are ellipsoid and smooth.]] When they are viewed in mass, such as with a [[spore print]], the [[spore]]s appear white. Observing with a light microscope reveals additional details: [[spore]]s are [[wikt:ellipsoid|ellipsoid]], smooth, and measure 6–8 by 3.5–5 [[micrometre|μm]]. They are pale yellow in [[Melzer's reagent]]. The [[basidia]] (spore-bearing cells) are 42–52 by 608 μm, and four-spored. There are no [[wikt:pleurocystidium|pleurocystidia]] or [[wikt:cheilocystidium|cheilocystidia]]. The gill tissue is made of branching [[hypha]]e about 7–12 μm wide. The [[pileipellis|cap cuticle]] is made of gelatinous, narrow (3–6 μm) hyphae which are repent (bent over) but typically with some erect free ends. [[Clamp connection]]s are present in the hyphae. ===Edibility=== The mushroom is [[edible mushroom|edible]], although it may not be appealing to many due to its sliminess. In China, a yak milk beverage is made with ''H. eburnus'' and [[yak]] milk, by [[lactic acid fermentation]] with ''[[Lactobacillus bulgaricus]]'', ''[[Streptococcus thermophilus]]'' and ''[[Lactobacillus acidophilus]]'' as mixed starter. ===Similar species=== A lookalike species of ''Hygrophorus eburneus'' is ''[[Hygrophorus piceae|H. piceae]]'', which differs by having a less slimy cap, dry to slightly viscid stem, and frequent association with spruce. ''[[Hygrophorus gliocyclus|H. gliocyclus]]'' is just as slimy, but has a cream-colored cap, thicker stalk, and grows with pine. The "snow white waxy cap" (''[[Hygrophorus borealis|H. borealis]]'') is also similar in appearance, but has a smaller cap diameter of up to {{convert|4.5|cm|in|abbr=on}}—and is not slimy.Roody, 1997, [https://books.google.com/books?id=5HGMPEiy4ykC&lpg=PA119&dq=Hygrophorus%20eburneus&pg=PA119#v=onepage&q=Hygrophorus%20eburneus&f=false p. 119]. Retrieved 2010-06-30. ''[[Hygrophorus cossus]]'', which typically grows with ''[[Quercus]]'' species, differs in its pale pinkish-buff cap and gills, and has a distinct sour odor; also, ''H. cossus'' does not have a potassium hydroxide [[Chemical tests in mushroom identification|reaction]] on the stem as does ''H. eburneus''. The "white slime mushroom" (''[[Limacella illinita]]'') has non-waxy gills that are free from attachment to the stalk.Roody, 1997, [https://books.google.com/books?id=5HGMPEiy4ykC&lpg=PA119&dq=Hygrophorus%20eburneus&pg=PA250#v=onepage&q=Hygrophorus%20eburneus&f=false p. 250]. Retrieved 2010-08-25. ==Habitat and distribution== The fruit bodies of ''H. eburneus'' grow on the soil, mostly in [[coniferous forest|coniferous woods]], thickets and grassy areas. The fungus prefers soil that is moist, [[mesic habitat|mesic]], [[loam]]y and [[calcareous]]. The fungus is widely distributed in North America. It is also found in Europe (Poland and Portugal), Israel and North Africa. ==Bioactive compounds== [[File:Gamma-oxocrotonic acids in Hygrophorus eburneus.png|thumb|500px|γ-Oxocrotonic acids found in ''Hygrophorus eburneus'']] Several [[fatty acid]]s with [[bactericide|bactericidal]] and [[fungicide|fungicidal]] activity have been isolated and identified from the fruit bodies of ''H. eburneus''. The [[biological activity|bioactive]] fatty acids are built upon a chemical structure called γ-oxocrotonate. The following gamma-oxocrotonate [[derivative (chemistry)|derivatives]] have been identified from the mushroom: (2''E'',9''E'')-4-oxooctadeca-2,9,17-trienoic acid, (2''E'',11''Z'')-4-oxooctadeca-2,11,17-trienoic acid, (''E'')-4-oxohexadeca-2,15-dienoic acid, (''E'')-4-oxooctadeca-2,17-dienoic acid, (2''E'',9''E'')-4-oxooctadeca-2,9-dienoic acid, (2''E'',11''Z'')-4-oxooctadeca-2,11-dienoic acid, (''E'')-4-oxohexadec-2-enoic acid, and (''E'')-4-oxooctadec-2-enoic acid. The compound (''E'')-4-oxohexadec-2-enoic acid has been investigated for potential use as a fungicide against the [[oomycete]] species ''[[Phytophthora infestans]]'', a causal agent of potato and tomato late blight disease. Additional [[secondary metabolites]] discovered in ''H. eburneus'' include the [[ceramide]] compound named ''hygrophamide'' ((2''S'',3''R'',4''R'',2{{'}}''R'')-2-(2'-hydroxy-9{{'}}''Z''-ene-tetracosanoylamino)-octadecane-1,3,4-triol), and the [[beta-Carboline|β-carboline]] [[alkaloid]]s known as ''harmane'' and ''norharmane''. The report of discovery of the latter two compounds in 2008 represents their first known occurrence in fungal fruit bodies. {{clear}} ==See also== [[List of Hygrophorus species|List of ''Hygrophorus''
